text: Principle: directory exactly one purpose. Rationale: Clarity: ambiguity things go Selective sharing: Archive ’s needed Automation: Tools can act directories knowing contents Restoration: Simple mapping label path Trade-offs: ✅ Structure immediately obvious ✅ Easy share/archive specific parts ❌ directories minimal structure ❌ redundancy (e.g., separate output-figures output-tables) trade-worth : clarity automation benefits outweigh slight increase directory count. title: Design
text: Principle: Version entire project state, individual files. Rationale: Coherence: files version X consistent Simplicity: One version number, per-file versions Traceability: Know exactly produced Restoration: Restore entire consistent state Trade-offs: ✅ Simpler mental model (one version) ✅ Guarantees consistency ❌ Version bumps even small changes ❌ Can’t mix versions different components trade-worth : Scientific outputs depend multiple inputs. Versioning whole project ensures can always reconstruct consistent state. Per-file versioning leads combinatorial explosion possible states.

title: Design
text: Principle: Project structure build behaviour _projr.yml, scattered across code. Rationale: Centralised: One place understand project configuration Readable: YAML human-readable Version-controlled: Configuration changes tracked Shareable: Easy share configuration across projects Trade-offs: ✅ Configuration explicit visible ✅ Easy diff merge configuration changes ❌ Less flexible code-based configuration ❌ YAML syntax can tricky trade-worth : research projects don’t need flexibility code-based configuration. benefits single, readable, version-controlled configuration file outweigh limitations.

title: Design
text: Principle: Separate safe iteration committed releases. Rationale: Safety: Dev builds can’t accidentally overwrite released outputs Speed: Dev builds skip versioning archiving Clarity: Explicit distinction “testing” “committing” Trade-offs: ✅ Safe experimentation ✅ Fast feedback loop ❌ Two commands remember (dev vs final) ❌ Cache directory can grow large trade-worth : safety speed benefits critical iterative research. cost remembering two commands minimal.

title: Design
text: Decision: Use x.y.z versioning (major.minor.patch) Rationale: Familiar: developers know SemVer Expressive: Can communicate scale changes Tooling: Many tools understand SemVer Alternative considered: Date-based versioning (2024-01-15) ✅ Chronological ordering ❌ Doesn’t communicate significance changes ❌ Multiple versions per day require disambiguation

title: Design
text: Decision: GitHub Releases default archive destination Rationale: Ubiquity: R projects already use GitHub Free: Unlimited public releases, generous private quotas Integrated: Works existing Git workflow Accessible: Web interface downloads Alternative considered: OSF primary ✅ Designed research ✅ Better large datasets ❌ Separate account/authentication ❌ Less familiar R developers Solution: Support ; default GitHub familiarity.

title: Design
text: Decision: Default clearing _output final builds Rationale: Correctness: Ensures outputs match current code cruft: Old outputs don’t linger Idempotency: code → outputs Alternative considered: Incremental updates ✅ Faster (update changed files) ❌ Risk stale files ❌ Non-deterministic (depends previous state) Solution: Clear default; allow override via PROJR_OUTPUT_CLEAR.

title: Design
text: Decision: Dev builds write _tmp/projr/v<version>/ _output Rationale: Safety: Can’t accidentally overwrite released outputs Isolation: Multiple dev builds don’t conflict Cleanup: Cache can deleted without losing work Alternative considered: Use _output flag prevent overwrites ✅ Simpler mental model (one output location) ❌ Risk accidental overwrites ❌ Harder keep dev release outputs separate

title: Design
text: Decision: Use YAML configuration Rationale: Familiar: R users know YAML (R Markdown, pkgdown) Readable: Comments, quotes strings Expressive: Supports lists, nested structures Alternatives considered: TOML: - ✅ Simpler syntax - ❌ Less familiar R ecosystem - ❌ Harder nest deeply JSON: - ✅ Strict, machine-friendly - ❌ Less human-readable (quotes, comments) - ❌ Harder hand-edit
